ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otosclerosis (Left Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral conductive hearing loss with Carhart notch at 2000 Hz, absent acoustic reflexes, and normal tympanometry (Type A).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Misophonia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports strong negative reaction to specific soft sounds and low tolerance, distinct from recruitment.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Previous Diagnosis - Incorrect)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Previous diagnosis ruled out by current findings of air-bone gaps and Weber lateralization to the affected ear.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To evaluate middle ear mobility and pressure.
To assess stapedial reflex arc and differentiate conductive vs sensorineural pathology.
To confirm laterality and type of hearing loss (conductive vs sensorineural).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation at a previous clinic 1 year prior. Results indicated asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, with mild low-frequency loss in the right ear and moderate rising to mild mixed (interpreted as SNHL) in the left ear. Tympanometry was reported as 'peaked' but lacked data; reflexes were not reported. The diagnosis was incorrect based on later findings.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: mild low-frequency SNHL rising to normal. Left ear: moderate rising to mild mixed loss (interpreted as SNHL). Missing bone conduction masking info.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs agreed with PTAs. Word recognition scores were 100% bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Reported as 'peaked' but no specific values recorded.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Current evaluation revealed normal hearing in the right ear and mild conductive hearing loss in the left ear, contrasting with the previous SNHL diagnosis. Key findings included a significant air-bone gap in the left ear, a Carhart notch at 2000 Hz, normal tympanograms, and absent acoustic reflexes, consistent with otosclerosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal hearing (0-10 dB HL). Left ear: Mild conductive loss (~40 dB HL flat) with 30-40 dB air-bone gaps and Carhart notch at 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs consistent with PTAs (Right 25 dB, Left 40 dB). Excellent word recognition (Right 92%, Left 96%).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally (Right 0.6 mL, Left 0.5 mL).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent bilaterally to ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Weber Tuning Fork
tests.result_summary: Lateralized to the left ear (512 Hz), confirming conductive component.

proposed_items: Surgical consultation (stapedectomy) for left ear otosclerosis
Amplification (hearing aids) as an alternative to surgery
Referral to otologist for medical management
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of conductive hearing loss (otosclerosis) versus the previous incorrect diagnosis of nerve damage
Counsel on the excellent prognosis for hearing improvement via surgery or hearing aids
Discuss the impact of pregnancy on management timeline (delaying surgery)
Address misophonia and sound sensitivity issues

escalation.rationale_short: To evaluate for ossicular chain fixation (otosclerosis) and discuss surgical options.

follow_up_plan.objective: Return for follow-up examination and discussion regarding corrective surgery after pregnancy.

expected_outcome: Diagnosis corrected from sensorineural hearing loss to conductive hearing loss (otosclerosis) in the left ear.
Patient was provided with a surgical option to improve hearing.
Surgical intervention was deferred for 1 year due to patient's pregnancy.
